Abstract: This paper presents an autobiographical account of a clinical psychologist whose career has been dedicated to the study of alcohol and alcohol use disorder (AUD). The narrative traces the author’s journey from doctoral training to becoming a leading researcher in the field, highlighting the pivotal role of mentoring in shaping their professional trajectory. The author discusses their contributions to the understanding of AUD through rigorous empirical research and their involvement in journal editing, which has facilitated the dissemination of critical findings. Additionally, the paper reflects on the importance of professional societies in fostering collaboration and advancing the field. The author’s experiences underscore the multifaceted nature of a career in clinical psychology, emphasizing the integration of research, mentorship, and service to the scientific community.
